endorse.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to express formal support or approval for someone or something
endorse.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The prime minister is unlikely to endorse this view.
endorse a proposal/an idea/a candidate etc
endorse.translation[0].definitions[1].de: if a famous person endorses a product or service, they say in an advertisement that they use and like it
endorse.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to sign your name on the back of a cheque to show that it is correct
endorse.translation[0].definitions[3].de: if your driving licence is endorsed for a driving offence, an official record is made on it to show that you are guilty of the offence
endorse.translation[0].definitions[3].no: Endorse is usually passive in this meaning
endorse.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to sign a formal document for something that you own so that ownership changes to someone else
endorse.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to sign your name on the back of a cheque, a BILL OF EXCHANGE etc so that it can be paid to someone other than the person whose name is written on it
endorse.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The bank could not confirm the endorsed signature so stolen cheques could be cashed long before anyone realised it.
endorse.translation[1].definitions[2].de: if a well-known person endorses a product, they say in an advertisement how good they think it is. People will buy the product because they like or trust the person
endorse.translation[1].definitions[3].de: to add a written condition to an insurance agreement
